 SECTION a PROJECT N e......| I. PROJECT DESIGN A. Background 1. The social and economic consequences of urban growth in Republic of Cate d'lvoire (RCI) are well documented. The expansion of cities has resulted in high infrastructure costs, and the inadequacies of land management, construction standards and housing finance have resulted in the multiplication and growth of squatter settlements -- which, in turn, has heightened environmental and public health concerns. Despite attempts by the Government and local elected officials over the past 20 years to provide decent living conditions to the urban population, conditions have worsened -- especially in the late 1980s and early 1990s, due to the downturn experienced by the economy. Aware that housing is critical to the general welfare and to social cohesiveness, the Government intends to implement a broad land development policy reform. As part of this new approach, the Government also intends to help modernize the mechanisms of housing finance -- a process already under way under the privatization policy. 2. The substantial social housing programs implemented by SICOGI and SOGEFIHA in the 1970s and 1980s, the land development operations implemented by the Government under Comptes de Terrains Urbains (CTU) and the creation of Compte de Mobilisation de 1 'Habitat (CDMH) have not prevented a deterioration of urban living conditions. As a consequence, emergency measures focusing primarily on squatter areas (e.g. under the on-going Municipal Support Project) are now necessary to improve the living conditions of the poorest segments of the population. The factors responsible for the persistent deterioration of these conditions remain: (i) the absence of a land market, which makes it almost impossible for the vast majority of urban dwellers to have access to land or to collateralize land for shelter financing purposes; (ii) high construction standards, which make legal developments unaffordable for most households; and (iii) the absence of a housing finance system linked with financial markets to provide a reliable source of funding for home financing. 3. An Integrated Approach for Reforming the Sector. The Government's past strategy of subsidizing land development and housing and providing subsidized housing credit has not worked. Experience in many other countries has established that, even if more resources could be allocated to subsidize housing development, such a policy would still remain ineffective, essentially because it would not prevent the most creditworthy segments of the population from appropriating most of the subsidies. Thus, improving the housing conditions of low-income households appears achievable only through the implementation of a new, broader and more diversified Government strategy for the
 - 2 - housing sector, encompassing major improvements to both land management and housing finance, and relying on the private sector. 4. Urban Land Management. While rehabilitating the housing sector can be achieved only through a major increase of the allocation of private resources to the sector (i.e. a major increase of the mortgage market), a prerequisite for such an increase is a reform of the land management system whereby land can be identified, transferred and mortgaged. For this purpose, a revision of related laws and regulations and an overhaul of the land management services are necessary. Such changes, however, will need to be made while taking into account local traditions. Also, building on existing structures will be desirable, to instill confidence among the operators in the housing market as well as the authorities responsible for monitoring its development. Such undertakings, therefore, should involve all participants from the private and public sectors, and only a process seeking a consensus on the conceptual framework of the reform can lead Government, banks, developers, realtors, lawyers, magistrates and notaries to participate in the reform. 5. Housing Finance. The various forms of Government housing subsidies (SICOGI, SOGEFIHA, CTU programs, CDMH) have catered for the middle class, contrary to their initial objectives, and should be replaced. Basically, housing finance should be provided through financial institutions and market offerings -- with public subsidies kept strictly for the poor and managed separately in a way ensuring that their purpose is effectively met. Relying on financial institutions (inter alia a secondary mortgage facility, to be created) and market offerings should simultaneously: (i) increase investment options for savings -- thus contribute to the mobilization of savings -- and help regulate the flow of investments; (ii) contribute to the broadening and strengthening of the financial sector; (iii) increase the volume of resources available for housing loans; and (iv) allow public funds to be better directed to the poor -- particularly through investments in priority infrastructure and squatter settlement upgrading. Furthermore, by reducing the risk of mismatch and allowing competition between institutions, the new system should result in a reduction of management costs and, therefore, of the cost of housing finance for the households. In parallel, risks to financial institutions will be reduced through measures such as the effective enforcement of foreclosures, and will be better distributed. B. Project Objectives 6. The project will support the detailed definition and the beginning of the implementation of a reform package for improving the efficiency and equity of urban land and housing markets. Specifically, it will: promote the development of a market for the provision of serviced land and housing, especially to the moderate and low income households;
 - 3 - * foster private investment in housing, by developing a market oriented housing finance system; and * strengthen the capacities of public and private sector institutions participating in the development and management of urban land and concerned with housing delivery. To see that new institutions build up their capacity and that new systems, standards and regulations are adopted, the project will also support testing these new elements through pilot operations in land titling, management and development, and in data management. C. Project Description 7. Under its land management and development chapter, the project will help: (i) set up a Land Management Agency for providing land to developers; (ii) establish a regulatory environment allowing private developers (through concession d'amenagement) to have access to and develop land, then sell plots; and (iii) regularize the legal status of a large fraction of existing properties. The project will also support improvements in land registration to benefit squatter settlements (of the type upgraded under the Municipal Support Program, MSP, financed by the IDA Credit 2704-IVC), and the definition of land development and construction standards compatible with the financial capabilities of low income households. 8. Under the project's housing finance chapter, the system will be reformed by: (a) creating new institutions and mechanisms (a secondary mortgage facility -- Societe de Refinancement Hypothecaire, SRH -- and a mortgage insurance mechanism (Fonds de Caution) to improve low-income households' access to credit) and preparing manuals to orient their operations; and (b) launching the first operations of private funds mobilization. In parallel, the project will support reforms ensuring that foreclosure regulations are enforced and collaterals can be effectively mobilized to provide security to lending institutions. 9. The project will support pilot operations through which the Government will have the opportunity to assess the benefits to be drawn from the different elements of the reforms and improve on the latter. The project will also help the Government improve its capacity to monitor its housing policy, through establishing the Housing Steering Committee (HSC), designing and creating a data base for monitoring the new policy and streamlining the agencies involved in land management. Finally, the project will provide equipment and operational support to the sector reforn and project management.
 -4 - D. Project Financing 10. ITF will contribute US$ 10 million equivalent to the financing of the project. The Government will provide US$ 1.7 million equivalent to finance part of the project's operating costs and to support its capacity building component. The Japanese Trust Fund has contributed US$ 0.2 million to finance the establishment and early operation of the project Coordination Unit (para. 46). France's Caisse .Franqaise de Developpement (CFD) will contribute US$ 0.1 million equivalent in parallel financing for technical assistance, essentially for auditing CDMH. CFD is likely to expand its contribution to integrate CDMH in SRH and assist in setting up its operational procedures once the detail of a SRH setup satisfactory to CFD is known. IFC has also expressed interest in participating and supporting SRH, and will clarify its position when detail of SRH structure as well as of its conditions and modes of operation becomes available. E. Project Risks 11. For years, the issues of land management and development and housing finance have been raised with the Government by the Bank and other donors, with limited success. However, as evidenced by its participation in recent urban sector work, the Government would now be committed to reorient its policies -- notably, to privatize land development and marketing and to reach lower income households, which can only come with a strong and sustained political commitment. However, as the private sector develops further, the Government's disengagement from the housing sector might be perceived as a threat by groups with vested interests arid, under their pressure, the Government might opt for short-term stop-gap measures against fundamental reforms. Should the Government follow such a course, serious rejpercussions would ensue for poverty alleviation and the development of the financial sector. ITF then should, at the time of the mid-term review, reconsider its support for this operation and for possible subsequent operations in the sector. 12. Other risks relate to housing finance. Although the private sector in many countries has shown its willingness to provide funds for housing finance, such a willingness has yet to be demonstrated in Cote d'Ivoire. As of a recent period, commercial banks were still somewhat reluctant to provide housing finance because they perceived high liquidity and credit risks in such lending: liquidity risks arising from the long term nature of housing loans and the short term character of bank deposits, and credit risks arising from possible defaults due to either borrowers' private circumstances or broader causes (e.g. rise in unemployment, or political disruption). The project will address these concerns through the creation of specialized institutions and regulations to reduce and redistribute these risks and to improve the affordability of housing. Finally, significant risks also relate to legal and political difficulties in enforcing foreclosures, and these will be addressed under the project through short-term technical assistance and training to the institutions involved in such enforcements.
 -5 - F. Project Benefits 13. The proposed project will improve development procedures and the provision of infrastructure designed more appropriately to meet the needs of shelter of the middle and low income urban households. By reducing the risks attached to the provision of mortgage finance, the project will also help ensure that the financial environment does not hamper anymore private financial institutions from allocating resources to housing finance. Thus, the project will facilitate and encourage the mobilization of private savings, investment in housing and, therefore, some further growth of the economy and the financial sector. Finally, the proposed project should lead to a very significant leverage of donors funds. G. Project Sustainability 14. Experience in a number of other countries has established that market-oriented systems of housing finance and development, based on an effective land registration system and affordable physical standards, adapt to evolving needs and circumstances and prove sustainable over time, because they are not constrained as highly subsidized systems are. Given in RCI (a) the panting demand for housing, (b) the large number of creditworthy borrowers (once housing investments compatible with households resources become eligible for financing) and (c) the significant reduction and more equitable sharing of financial risks, the new financial instruments and institutions should prove both viable and durable. II. PROJECT COMPONENTS A. Background 15. Redefining the Role of Government. Past land management and development and housing construction programs implemented according to regulations and physical standards set by the Government and marketed at below market prices, have proved inappropriate to address the housing crisis. These programs have acted as disincentives for the mobilization of private housing producers, have failed to regulate the supply of housing both in terms of costs and volume, and have created rationing. In practice, these programs have benefited a small number of households and had an adverse economic and social impact, as they have encouraged speculation and tied-up capital unproductively. 16. Whereas the Government used to fund public real estate companies and was itself a real estate developer, now -- because of the need to reduce its budget deficit -- it cannot provide any meaningful support to the sector. It must, therefore, create the conditions needed to mobilize funds from the private sector. For this purpose, clear legal and fiscal policies are needed to facilitate the emergence of a housing market in which properly informed real estate developers, financial institutions and investors will participate. The
 - 6 - Government's new approach has now been spelled out in a Sector Policy Letter submitted to IDA as a condition of Board presentation. 17. Creating a Real Estate Market. Households with monthly income of less than CFAF 150,000 represent at least 80 percent of Cote d'Ivoire's urban population and their demand for housing can be met only by a market that would ensure the large scale availability of both serviced land and housing loans. Since making land available is the first step towards meeting the demand for housing, the Land Management Reform, described in section B below, is key to establishing this new environment. The next bottleneck rests with the real estate finance system, which should not be constrained by shortcomings in financial risks coverage arrangements and/or related legal setups, or by State budgetary considerations. Where Government assistance might be needed, it should be earmarked for the poorest groups and effectively targeted towards needy households; also, to minimize possible slippage and ensure the desirable transparency, such assistance should be fully distinct from the commercial credit system. The Housing Finance Reform, described in section C below, is essential to see that the demand for housing finance become explicit, and can be met. B. The Land Development and Management Reform Detailed Design and Implementation Startup 18. Background. Cote d'lvoire's new housing policy rests squarely on the management of land. While the State should have a role in urban development, it must also be recognized that, in the past, the State has proved not to be sufficiently effective in guiding the transition from customary to private land ownership, or in organizing mechanisms to pave the way to private real estate ownership. The situation still prevailing facilitates practices that undermine common law principles and, therefore, expectations are that the State should experience increasing difficulties overseeing the transition to private ownership. The growing ascendancy of real estate and land promoters, is a recent phenomenon and strongly argues in favor of removing the production of serviced lots from State prerogative. The large-scale production of serviced land can be achieved only if the private sector is involved in land development. Towards this end, in the future, the development of land according to agreed upon specifications will be contracted out to promoters by the State, through a land management agency, to be created under the project.. The measures and reforms listed below should contribute significantly to improving the supply of serviced land. 1. Creating and Launching a Land ManagementAgency (AGEF) 19. The Urban Development Department (Service du Domaine Urbain) in the Ministry of Housing, traditionally responsible for implementing the land reserves policy, will continue to hold title to land reserves. However, in the future, the Department will delegate the operational responsibility of assembling land reserves through purchasing land from customary chiefs (purge des droits coutumiers), to a land management agency,
 -7 - Agence de Gestion Fonciere (AGEF) to be created no later than December 31, 1997. Under this arrangement, AGEF will be a service provider to Service du Domaine Urbain; it will also help local governments establish and manage land reserves. The project will help define AGEF's functions, responsibilities and resource needs and draft the agency's bylaws. Furthermore, an inventory of Service des Ventes Immobilires (SVI) will be made and its resources allocated to the AGEF, and a Law will convert CTU into a Land Development Fund. The cost of this project subcomponent (see Matrix: measures #1-2) is estimated at US$ 250,000. 20. To start building some experience in its land assembly function, AGEF, under the project, will undertake a first operation of land acquisition, testing how effective it is at carrying out settlement of customary land rights (purge des droits coutumiers). The cost of this project subcomponent (see Matrix: measure #3) is estimated at US$ 100,000. 2. Introducing Private Land Development Thtrough Concession Contracts 21. In the future, land development will be carried out by private developers under contract with AGEF. For developing a site, AGEF will have consultants define the technical and financial specifications (Cahier des Charges) to be annexed to the concession agreement, call for bids from developers, analyze and compare the bids, then award a development concession. Developers, once awarded a concession, will become temporary owners of the land, will develop it according to Cahier des Charges, and be allowed to sell building plots with clear title, without having to obtain a certification of edification (constat de mise en valeur) as done at present. Service du Domaine Urbain will oversee the compliance with all the contractual clauses in the concession agreement. Procedures for the above modus operandi are detailed in the draft implementation decree of the Law on concession. This will ensure diversity and autonomy of, as well as competition among potential concession holders and compliance with the Law on concession. Promulgation of the above Law and decree -- already approved by the Parliament and the Council of Ministers as a condition of Board presentation -- is a condition of Credit effectiveness. A model deferred delivery sales contract will also be prepared under the project, for use by land developers in their sale of serviced plots, which should help them reduce their needs of prefinancing. The cost of this project subcomponent (see Matrix: measure #4) is estimated at US$ 50,000. 22. To test the new practice of land development through concession contracts, the effectiveness of such contracts and their enforcement by the Administration, the project will finance technical and financial studies for two operations. These pilot operations will provide an opportunity to test the assessment by AGEF of developers' potential capacities and its process of selecting developers, and to assess the time needed to turn the stock over and AGEF's ability to control the quality of such operations. The cost of this project subcomponent (see Matrix: measure #5) is estimated at US$ 2.8 million.
 - 8 - 3. Clearing the Land Titling Backlog 23. The primary obstacle to the development of a mortgage market in C6te d'lvoire is the scarcity of mortgage guarantees secured by a land title. According to Cote d'Ivoire's law, even if a plot has been developed, a concession provisoire (temporary land title, transferable, in principle) on this plot can be canceled by the State. As a consequence, financial institutions are hesitant to accept temporary titles as security. A priority, therefore, is to increase the number of legitimate land titles that cannot be legally contested. This can be achieved readily by regularizing the status of all properties with a temporary land title or properties of an otherwise uncertain legal status. This should have the effect of (i) increasing substantially the size of the market; and, as a consequence, (ii) permitting more pertinent assessments of the quality of mortgage guarantees. 24. Under the project, the backlog in legal registration would be caught up with by adopting streamlined procedures recently drafted by the Government. In accordance with these procedures, (a) plots awarded more than five years ago and still undeveloped, or the development of which is valued at less than CFAF 1 million, will revert to the State; and (b) constats de mise en valeur will be delivered on the basis of fiscal evaluations already available with the Administration. Estimates are that the status of at least 95,000 properties could be regularized in about 3 years. Support to this operation will be provided under the project, through the provision of the necessary means to the Directorates of Conservation Fonciere in the Ministry of Finance and Service du Domaine Urbain (see Matrix: measure #6). This project subcomponent is estimated to cost US$ 200,000. 25. Under the project, a pilot operation in two districts will give an opportunity to test the new procedures before they are adopted and followed throughout Abidjan. Under the project, (a) regularization procedures will be finalized; (b) an inventory of the land status will be carried out in the districts selected; and (c) the implementation of the procedures will be fully documented so as to permit further improvements to these procedures as deemed necessary. The cost of this project subcomponent (see Matrix: measure #7) is estimated at US$ 150,000. 4. Reducing t/he Cost of Serviced Land and Construction 26. Under the project, a detailed study will be carried out to define standards for land development and housing construction (the latter, in consultation with the industry) consistent with local conditions and constraints -- notably, on the basis of affordability levels, to ensure that the market price of serviced plots and shelter units are affordable by low income households. Also, in collaboration with the inclustry, (a) an analysis of the impact of taxation on the building industry will be carried out to identify ways to remove disincentives for builders to enter the formal sector, as most of them are presently in the informal sector; and (b) specific actions will be undertaken to encourage a more intensive use of labor and a greater utilization of local materials. Finally, the existing system of duties on land transfers will be reviewed to identify ways by which transaction costs can
 - 9 - be reduced and thus the land market made more active. The cost of this project subcomponent (see Matrix: measure #8) is estimated at US$ 240,000. 27. To test the conditions of production and marketing of low cost developed plots, the project will support two pilot operations to develop such plots to be sold at market prices to low-income households, i.e. households with monthly income of less than CFAF 200,000 in 1996 terms. Plots will be sold, or "rented" under a system of long term allocation (baux emphyteothiques) payable in a single up-front payment. The cost of this project subcomponent (see Matrix: measure #9) is estimated at US$ 1.8 million. 5. Accelerating the Privatization of State Owned Land and Housing 28. Compared with other countries in the region, C6te d'Ivoire has a relatively large public stock of land and housing units. The use of this stock could be greatly improved if its management were to be private; correspondingly, market growth and fluidity would be greatly enhanced by such a transfer. Also, part of the demand -- particularly, that for low and moderately priced housing units -- could be met by facilitating the purchase of this stock. This would require that regulations be amended so that the State-owned stock can be put up for sale. The prerequisite analyses, the preparation of such amendments and the preparation of model sale contracts would be provided for under the project. The cost of this project subcomponent (see Matrix: measure #10) is estimated at US$ 70,000. C. The Housing Finance Reform Detailed Design and Implementation Startup 29. Background. The present "lease with option to buy" system often results in sales below the market value. This is not a sound basis for market financing and affects adversely the development of such financing. A system of mortgage lending with transfer of property at the time of sale is far more appropriate and conducive to wider market financing. Under the project, new regulations and contracts will be developed (a) to facilitate the sale of new housing, as well as the turnover of the existing stock; and (b) to make it possible for developers to secure prefinancing for their operations. Also, the Government, to encourage investors to invest in jointly owned property, will revise joint ownership regulations. 30. Although a number of elements of a full financial system are already operational in RCI, a market in housing loans does not yet exist. The project, therefore, will examine means of increasing the mobilization of term resources, for the banking system to be able to expand and diversify its operation in mortgage lending. Other objectives will be to expand the range and depth of the financial sector and to enhance competitiveness among lenders -- leading inter alia to lower costs of housing finance to households.
 - 10- 1. Creating a Secondary Mortgage Financing Facility (SRH) 31. Equipped with the necessary guarantees, a secondary mortgage financing facility - - the creation of which no later than June 30, 1999 will be supported under the project, as Societe de Refinancement Hypothecaire (SRH) -- should be able to provide the banking system with long-term resources in amounts less constrained than under the CDMH State-funded scheme, and thus facilitate access to credcit for potential homeowners. SRH's structure of capital, terms of offerings, borrowing capacity, etc. will be defined in detail under the project -- seeing that the SRH operation be coherent with, and fully integrated in the whole Ivorian financial sector reformed along the lines soon to be defined under a separate ITF operation, the proposed Financial Sector Development (FSD) project. Expectations are that SRH would basically be a private entity, mobilizing funds on the capital market, in which financial and non-financial institutions would participate. CDMH operations, as run in the past, will be discontinued. Government assets in CDMH will be assessed and would probably be transferred to SRH. 32. Improvements in cost transparency and in the quality of guarantees offered by borrowers (para 35), combined with competition among lending institutions, should make it possible for the cost of funds for borrowers to be close to that of medium term resources. In turn, moderate costs of funds should result in expanding the borrowing and investment capacity of households, and bring better housing within reach of the less affluent social groups. 33. Another important benefit expected from the establishment of SRH is the introduction of new long-term savings products on the market, which will greatly contribute to the modernization, and enhancement of the efficiency of the financial sector as sought under the FSD operation. For, a better match could then be achieved between the instruments offered and the needs and opportunities of participants in the market -- notably, insurance companies and pension funds. Setting up the SRH will be supported by the project. The cost of this project subcomponent (see Matrix: measure #11) is estimated at US$ 440, 000. 2. Creating a Guarantee Fund to Improve the Access of Low-Income Households 34. The feasibility will be studied of creating a guarantee fund (Fonds de Caution) no later than June 30, 1999 -- a mortgage insurance mechanism to improve households' access to credit -- intended specifically to supplement the guarantees given by low- income households. Financed in comparable shares by borrowers' deposits and allocations from the State, the Fund would be used exclusively to guarantee loans for low-cost serviced plots or housing units (CFAF 5 million or less) meeting minimum standards, yet remain affordable by low-income families. Funds would be used to cover borrowers' defaults in the event of unemployment or disability -- death being already covered by compulsory insurance or other ways. The cost of this project subcomponent (see Matrix: measure #12) is estimated at US$ 240,000.
 - 11 - 3. Strengthening the Legal Enforcement of Foreclosures 35. To promote the realization of securities, the project will seek to strengthen the role, capabilities and capacities of Courts, by training magistrates and legal assistants, by computerizing court proceedings and by establishing an information link between the Courts and the Land Management Department in the Ministry of Finance (see Matrix: measure #13). The cost of this project subcomponent was estimated at US$ 220,000. 4. Stimulating the Real Estate Market 36. The project will develop rules and procedures to enable private developers awarded a Convention de Concession d'Amenagement to use it as security to obtain from banking and financial institutions, loans to help meet their financing needs. As already mentioned in para 23 and 28, model contracts of various types will also be drafted with the project support. 37. Under the project, a number of cases will be surveyed and analyzed, and recommendations on tax exemptions for housing loans will be made. Similarly, an analysis will be carried out of the likely impact of other possible exemptions (e.g. of VAT, BIC) on real estate promotion, and recommendations will be submitted accordingly. The cost of this project subcomponent (see Matrix: measures #14-15) is estimated at US$ 100,000. 5. Stimulating Housing Savings 38. The project will study the possibility of granting tax exemptions for borrowers on the interests paid on SRH-refinanced housing loans, and of exempting SRH from BIC. Also, after a careful review of the possible impact of such exemptions, recommendations will be submitted as deemed appropriate on exemptions for revenues from bonds issued by SRH, and for interest paid on housing savings accounts. The cost of this project subcomponent (see Matrix: measure #16) is estimated at US$ 90,000. D. The Capacity Building Program 39. Background. Even after the Government has implemented legislative, regulatory and institutional reforms giving new responsibilities to housing sector operators, the Administration will still need to be the arbitrator. The State will not invest large amounts of public funds in housing anymore, but it will continue playing a regulatory role and ensuring that rules are understood by all the parties involved. It will also have to impose sanctions occasionally to limit abuses that might result from a new freedom in real estate transactions. Charts of sector performance will be developed -- based on performance indicators -- for savings and investment, real estate market, the impact of taxation on the level of investments, the fluidity of the market, and the success of Govermment agencies in restructuring the land registration and development system.
 -12- 1. Streamlining and Improving the Administration of Land Management 40. Administrative services concerned with land management are distributed between two ministries. Service du Domaine Urbain, Service de Z'Urbanisme and Service de la Topographie, all responsible for managing land registered by the State, are part of the Ministry of Housing. Direction du Domaine, du Cadastre, de 1'Enregistrement et du Timbre (DCFHC), which guarantees private titles and assesses property taxes, is part of the Ministry of Finance. The roles of these different services will be revisited and redefined as deemed desirable in the context of the reforms undertaken. A preliminary distribution of responsibilities -- to be confirmed under the project -- would be the following: the role of Service du Domaine Urbain would be limited to the registration of the land to the name of the State, and to overseeing the operation of AGEF. DCFHC would remain the guarantor of property rights on plots purchased. Such changes should have far reaching organizational consequences, -- including the transfer of Service du Domaine Urbain to the Ministry of Finance. These will be examined in detail under the project, and specific action plans will be developed accordingly (see Matrix: measure #17). The cost of this project subcomponent is estimated at US$ 300,000. 41. Under the project, three operations will be undertaken to support this strengthening of the sector management. First, a prime data base will be established from the documents of Service du Domaine Urbain, DCFHC and Bureau National d'Etudes Techniques pour le Developpement (BNETD). The data base will be used by policymakers, by all administrative departments involved in land management and by developers, and will facilitate the transfer of land (see Matrix: measure #18). Second, a public information campaign targeting households and other groups -- e.g. professionals, associations -- will be undertaken (see Matrix: measure #19) with the participation of the actors concerned with the sectoral strategy. Third, a Real Estate Guide will be developed and will be one of the main instrument in the information campaign (see Matrix: measure # 20). Estimates are that these operations will cost in total US$ 1.0 million (0.1, 0.8 and 0.1 respectively). 2. Broadening the Tax Base 42. The project will help rationalize procedures for assessing taxes on land and on properties, by using surveys to determine benchmark premises (by zone, category of housing, etc.). Such rationalization of procedures should lead to a substantial increase of revenues from land and real estate taxation; estimates are that the tax return from properties which would be registered in a simplified way (see para 24) could be in the vicinity of CFAF 17 billion per year. The project will support the review of taxes on real estate registration and transfers and the development of related recommendations. The project will also finance the implementation of a computerized system for real estate taxation purposes (see Matrix: measures #21-22). The cost of this project subcomponent is estimated at US$ 190,000.
 - 13 - 3. Upgrading the Management of Community Housing Developments 43. The existing housing stock in C6te d'Ivoire, especially housing built by parastatal companies, is deteriorating rapidly because of the lack of maintenance of buildings and open spaces. In order to encourage implementation of a uniform system for managing community housing developments, the project will finance a qualitative survey of a sample of 200 Abidjan households living in SOGEFIHA and SICOGI housing developments (which number 40,000 units); see Matrix; measure #23. The cost of this project subcomponent is estimated at US$ 100,000. 4. Providing Training and Specialized Professional Advice 44. To promote a broader knowledge of urban development planning and law, the project will provide professional and research training on a variety of subjects and, in particular, on urban and real estate laws (see Matrix: measure #24), addressing general as well as specialized topics for the benefit inter alia of concerned professionals who wish to improve their trade. Advice will also be provided under the project for the development, the organization and the supervision of the land developer profession. The cost of the professional services involved in these supports is estimated at US$ 270,000. 5. StrengtheningProject Management 45. To achieve the project objectives, an efficient coordination of all parties involved in these reforms will be needed. For that purpose, three small Technical Units will be established in each of the ministries primarily concerned: Housing, Finance and Justice. The activities of these Units will be supervised by a Coordination Unit. The Coordination Unit will act as the project implementation agency; it will prepare the decisions of, and report to the Housing Steering Committee (HSC), chaired by the Minister of Housing and composed of the other Ministers concerned. A Coordinator has been designated by the Government to manage the Coordination Unit. Recommendations to the HSC will stem from the analysis and monitoring of various data (inter alia land registration; inventories of allocation notices, undeveloped land, sites developed but not built) managed by the agencies responsible. Under the project, equipment and operational support will be provided for the Coordination Unit, as well as technical assistance to the Technical Units. Cost estimates for this project subcomponent are US$ 1.8 million.

doc.repnme: Cote d'Ivorie - Urban Land Management and Housing Finance Reforms Technical Assistance Project
doc.abstracts: The Urban Land Management and Housing Finance Reforms Technical Assistance Project will support the detailed definition and beginning of implementation of a reform package for improving the efficiency and equity of urban land and housing markets. Specifically, it will: (i) promote the development of a market for the provision of serviced land and housing, especially to moderate and low income households; (ii) foster private investment in housing; and (iii) strengthen the capacity of public and private sector institutions involved in the development and management of urban land and housing delivery. The project will support pilot operations in land titling, management and development, as well as, data management. The project consist of three components: a) land management reform, namely i) creating and launching the Agence de Gestion Fonciere (AGEF), ii) developing through concession, iii) reducing development costs, iv) clearing the titling backlog, and v) privatizing public real state; b) housing finance reform by i) creating and launching the Societe de Refinancement Hypothecaire (SRH), ii) creating a security fund, iii) enforcing foreclosures, iv) stimulating the real state market, and v) stimulating housing savings; and c) capacity building consisting of i) land management support operations, ii) tax base management, iii) public housing management, iv) develop professional and research training at the University on Urban and Real Estate Law, and v) promote the organization of the developers' profession.
